generated_json.title: Chief Complaint
content: Recurrent cyst on wrist with recurrence after prior surgical removal, now requiring aspiration

generated_json.title: History of Present Illness
content: The patient reports a recurrent cyst on the wrist that has reappeared after a prior surgical removal approximately 8 years ago. The cyst is noted to recur with repetitive activities involving wrist extension, such as push-ups and bench presses. The patient describes the current cyst as increasingly bothersome, prompting the desire for aspiration. The patient has previously undergone surgical excision of a similar cyst and notes a residual scar. The current episode began after a delay in treatment, and the patient is now seeking intervention due to mild discomfort. The patient is also experiencing persistent sensory changes in the lower leg following a prior nerve surgery, including tingling, numbness, and a sensation of the leg 'falling asleep' upon movement. These symptoms are attributed to nerve regeneration, particularly in the medial aspect of the knee, where an interposition graft was performed. The patient reports that the sensation is tolerable and not painful, but still noticeable. The patient is uncertain whether the symptoms are due to nerve regeneration or muscle constriction. The patient is currently undergoing physical therapy and strengthening exercises, which may exacerbate symptoms. The patient expresses difficulty distinguishing between normal recovery sensations and abnormal discomfort. The patient is open to further evaluation and treatment if symptoms become bothersome.
generated_json.instruction:

generated_json.title: Past Medical History
content: Prior surgical excision of a wrist cyst 8 years ago; history of nerve surgery on the right leg involving right soft tissue neurolysis, interposition grafting for the medial tibial nerve, and RPNI (reversed posterior nerve interposition) for the anterior tibial nerve. The patient underwent surgery in January/February, with postoperative recovery ongoing. No other significant past medical conditions reported.

sub-section.title: Assessment
content: Benign cyst, recurrent, right wrist (ICD-10: D37.2)
Post-surgical nerve regeneration, right medial tibial nerve (ICD-10: Z51.89)
Post-surgical status, right anterior tibial nerve (ICD-10: Z51.89)

sub-section.title: Plan
content: Schedule aspiration of the recurrent wrist cyst under local anesthesia with IV sedation.
Perform surgical excision of the cyst with removal of the stalk at the wrist joint.
Consider excision of the residual skin tag if desired, though it may not be covered by insurance.
Refer patient to hand therapy for nerve desensitization and nerve glide exercises.
Initiate home exercise program focused on nerve desensitization and gradual strengthening.
Monitor for recurrence of the wrist cyst and consider repeat excision if recurrence occurs.
Continue observation of the right lower leg sensory symptoms, as they are likely part of the nerve regeneration process.
Reassess the medial tibial nerve symptoms in 6–12 months; consider further intervention if symptoms persist or worsen.
sub-section.instruction: Detail the healthcare provider's plan of action to manage the patient's condition, specifying treatments, medications (include ongoing medications briefly), procedures, therapies, lifestyle modifications, referrals to specialists, patient education on condition and medications, and recommendations for counselings or support services. Dont provide any follow up details in this section, provide everything in a list.

generated_json.title: Follow Up
content: Next Appointment: Schedule aspiration and potential excision of the wrist cyst within the next 1–2 weeks. Follow-up with hand therapy within 2 days of the procedure. Review of nerve symptoms in 6–12 months.

Review and Adjustments: Assess response to aspiration and surgical excision. Evaluate progress of nerve regeneration and adjust therapy plan as needed. Reassess need for further surgical intervention if symptoms persist.
